subject: Re: New file uploaded to Read_Alphabet
msgSnippet: Dave, Thanks for your interest in QS.  I have reviewed some of the handwritten senior QS examples you have been uploading. While there is a logic to your
messageBody:
Dave,

Thanks for your interest in QS.  I have reviewed some of the handwritten senior QS examples you have been uploading. While there is a logic to your mirror-image "l," I find it a little disconcerting, and I don't read it that automatically, at least at first blush.  The first one I encountered appeared to me as a misshapen "k."  It took me a moment to realize what it was.

Just because a letter can be reversed doesn't necessarily mean it is a good idea.  QS has been around for roughly 45 years and to my knowledge no one in this group has previously proposed reversing "l."  Thus, the penlifts you are addressing have not seemed a problem to people up to this point.

With time I would no doubt become acclimated to the reversed "l.'  On the other hand, I believe it fair to say that Kingsley Read was not overly concerned about eliminating every possible penlift in senior QS.  QS grew out of Read's work with the Shaw alphabet.  In addition to other improvements, Read's plan in developing senior QS seems to me to have been that it would be faster to write than the Shaw alphabet because it is more cursive.  That being said, however, the impulse toward connecting letters should not impede legibility and ease of reading.  In traditional orthography, we have print and cursive two distinct varieties of writing.  Senior QS is a blend between the two and Read was not unduly concerned when a penlift had to be made.

I would be curious to hear what others think.

Moira:  what say you?  I suspect you have used QS longer than anyone else in the group.

Paige Gabhart
